thread.title: New Zealand sprint cyclist Eddie Dawkins gets silver at Oceania Championships
thread.title_full: New Zealand sprint cyclist Eddie Dawkins gets silver at Oceania Championships

author: Scott Donaldson
title: New Zealand sprint cyclist Eddie Dawkins gets silver at Oceania Championships
text:
New Zealand sprint cyclist Eddie Dawkins gets silver at Oceania Championships SCOTT DONALDSON Last updated 22:57, October 10 2015 DIANNE MANSON/GETTY IMAGES 
Eddie Dawkins of New Zealand competes in the Elite Men Sprint semifinals in Invercargill. 
New Zealand's Eddie Dawkins had to settle for a silver medal in the men's sprint at the Oceania Track Cycling Championships in Invercargill after finishing behind classy Australian Matthew Glaetzer. 
Dawkins, who was part of the successful gold medal-winning Kiwi team pursuit team earlier in the championships, was no match for the Aussie in the final - who continued his rich vein of form from qualifying to win in two races. 
Earlier in the event, Glaetzer rode a New Zealand all comer's record in qualifying of 9.797 seconds, to advance ahead of compatriot Patrick Constable and Dawkins. 
In the semifinals, Dawkins overcame Constable in three tightly-contested races, while Glaetzer accounted for Kiwi sprint rider and eventual bronze medallist Sam Webster in two races. 
The Southland rider conceded that it was difficult to beat his Australian opponent. 
"It is hard, the Oceanias are a target for both Australia and New Zealand, they brought their A-Game and we tried to topple them, but it didn't work out for us today," he said. 
Advancing to the final after three semis added to the challenge for the local rider. 
"I think I cooked myself a bit going to three in the semifinal, but that is sprint racing, I will get him next time. The hardest thing is that there is a small window after racing the third semifinal to racing in the final, I came off the bike, sat down and went back out and I just had nothing left, I tried my hardest but I just couldn't pull anything together " he said. 
Glaetzer has a strong record against Dawkins. 
"He is a fast man and it is hard to keep up sometimes, he loves this track and he seems to ride really well here. He is fast, he has beaten me both times we have been at the Oceanias here," Dawkins said. Ad Feedback 
In the men's omnium, Australian Sam Welsford produced a strong performance to win the gold medal with 245 points, after winning the scratch race, elimination, the one-kilometre time trial and flying lap. 
Kiwi Aaron Gate finished second with 224 points after winning the individual pursuit and points race, while fellow kiwi Nick Kergozou finished third with 205 points. 
Australia's Georgia Baker leads the women's omnium after three events on 118 points after winning the individual pursuit and elimination, where she sits ahead of New Zealand riders Lauren Ellis on 106 and Kirstie James on 104. 
New Zealand beat Australia in the under-19 team pursuit, overtaking them with an impressive ride by the team consisting of Thomas Sexton, Joshua Scott, Hugo Jones and Connor Brown. 
There was success for local riders in the under-19 sprints, with sixteen-year-old Bradly Knipe surviving a crash in his semifinal to win the title giving him three gold medals for the championships, while Emma Cumming claimed a silver medal in the women's event behind Australian rider Tahlay Christie. 
In the women's under-19 omnium, Kiwi rider Emily Shearman leads after three events on 118 points, after winning the elimination and individual pursuit. 
The Oceania championships finish on Sunday at the SIT Velodrome in Invercargill. - Stuff
